intro: Corymbostachys elytraria, commonly known as the golden mistflower, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble daisies. The plant produces showy yellow flowers that bloom in late summer to early autumn, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. Corymbostachys elytraria is often cultivated in gardens for its ornamental value and ability to thrive in partial shade.
